articles.title: Chinese researchers create an AI inspired by the human brain that surpasses classic models
articles.summary: Researchers at the Chinese Academy of Sciences have unveiled Spikingbrain, a groundbreaking AI system that mimics the efficiency of the human brain. It is 100 times faster than conventional language models and requires less than 2% of the training data. It's a paradigm shift away from brute-force computation and towards a more elegant, biologically inspired approach. The development also carries significant geopolitical weight due to China's access to advanced hardware.

articles.title: Why Ai Is Not an Issue for Fraudsters at the Moment
articles.summary: Artificial intelligence is currently on everyone's lips, but the industry is still unimpressed by the development. Internet fraudsters have not yet used artificial intelligence and there are reasons for this, as well as reasons why it's not being used by the industry.

articles.title: The End of the Teachers?
articles.author: El Comercio
articles.summary: Alpha schools, which teach with artificial intelligence, opened in Miami. According to their Internet portal, they are privatized and they teach only with AI. The school's manager contacted their managers to find out if they are revolutionary or just passing fashion. The manager confirmed that they are private.

articles.title: Artificial intelligence helps break barriers for Hispanic homeownership
articles.summary: Some mortgage experts are turning to artificial intelligence to bridge the gap between Spanish-speaking and non-Spanish-speaking loan officers. They want AI to help loan officers find the best lender for a potential homeowner's specific situation, explain the process clearly and navigate residency, visa or income requirements.

articles.title: Apple Sets New Standard with 256 GB Minimum Storage, Prompting Industry Shifts
articles.author: Sophie Lin
articles.summary: Comment circulating online suggests a growing disillusionment with the current wave of Artificial Intelligence technology. The global Artificial Intelligence market was valued at approximately $150.82 billion in 2023 and is projected to reach $1,597.1 billion by 2030. Apple's reputation and ability to integrate technology seamlessly into its ecosystem could give it a significant advantage.

articles.title: Lost in America: Feeling Like a Stranger at Home
articles.summary: In the last year, nearly 40% of US adults have used AI tools like ChatGPT. The rapid adoption of AI is creating a significant skills gap. The most disruptive change will come from businesses built from the ground up with AI at their core. The development of robust regulatory frameworks is crucial to ensure that AI is used responsibly and ethically.

articles.title: Figure AI: $675M to Build Humanoid Robots
articles.author: Sophie Lin
articles.summary: There was a billion dollars invested in Figure Robotics. The focus is on making robots useful and addressing the ethical implications of increasingly sophisticated automation. Anthropomorphic robotic hands are gaining prominence. Autonomy without GPS is no longer a luxury, it's a necessity for expanding the operational envelope of robots.

articles.title: AI like Chat GPT and Grammarly blur the line between class work and cheating
articles.summary: Artificial intelligence is transforming how students learn and study and how teachers teach. It's creating confusion over what constitutes academic dishonesty. Many schools initially banned use of AI after ChatGPT launched in late 2022. Now teachers are integrating AI into their lessons and teaching students how to use AI as a study aid.

articles.title: Local View: Rethinking NU for an AI-driven future
articles.author: Jeremy Hosein
articles.summary: Jeremy Hosein is a neurosurgeon and a candidate for the University of Nebraska Board of Regents. He is concerned about the future of the state university and its role in preparing students for a future defined by rapid change and complexity. He argues that the traditional academic mold cannot meet the needs of the AI era and the university must rethink its mission.

articles.title: ICSAN Pushes For Policy-Driven AI Adoption To Reform Governance
articles.summary: Mrs Uto Ukpanah is the president and chairman of the Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators of Nigeria (ICSAN). She believes Nigeria should embrace Artificial Intelligence as a transformational force in governance and public administration. This assertion was made at the 49th Annual Conference held in Lagos.

articles.title: Analog Devices' (ADI) Dividend History and its Impact on Dividend Paying Stocks Portfolios
articles.author: Vardah Gill
articles.summary: Analog Devices, Inc. (NASDAQ:ADI) is included among the 12 Best Dividend Paying Stocks to Buy Now. ADI develops and sells high-performance analog, mixed-signal, and digital signal processing chips that power a wide range of uses, including industrial automation, automotive systems, consumer electronics, and advanced communications networks. The company has raised its payouts for 21 years straight and currently pays a quarterly dividend of $0.99 per share.

articles.title: Lights, camera, algorithms: AI innovation for film
articles.author: Curt Doty
articles.summary: I've been encouraging AI adoption in the New Mexico film industry for two and a half years. New Mexico has always been a haven for artistic innovation. Netflix's $2 billion investment in Albuquerque and the $740 million in direct production spending in 2024 show we're not just another flyover location.

articles.title: Sam Altman reveals which jobs could be lost to AI: Here's who's most at risk
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: As artificial intelligence (AI) continues to transform the global workplace, questions about which jobs will survive and which will vanish have never been more urgent. OpenAI Chief Executive Officer Sam Altman shares his insights into the roles he believes are most vulnerable to automation and claims that current customer support that happens over a phone or computer will lose their jobs.

articles.title: One cool perk about having tattoos is that it's harder for AI to replicate
articles.author: Ljeonida Mulabazi
articles.summary: TikTok creator Ashleigh shares a video explaining why she doesn't stress as much about AI 'twins' because tattoos can throw AI off in ways that are easy to spot. Other social media users have noticed that AI tends to stumble when it comes to body art.

articles.title: Apollo 68080: Next-Gen FPGA Amiga is Back!
articles.author: Sophie Lin
articles.summary: Apollo sold out its initial run of 40 'Codename Unicorn' Amiga A6000s in hours. The resurgence of the Amiga is not just about reliving childhood memories, but about alternative computing experiences, customizable hardware, and a rejection of planned obsolescence.

articles.title: One cool perk about having tattoos is that it's harder for AI to replicate
articles.author: The Daily Dot
articles.summary: When people talk about artificial intelligence, the risks are often front and center. People worry about scammers using AI to copy their voice to trick family members or about likenesses being stolen and repurposed in inappropriate ways. Having tattoos helps prevent people from making a successful AI twin of you.

articles.title: Are we still using our brains, even today?
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: A vast majority of people are still using their brains despite the invasion of generative artificial intelligence into their lives, as it is the most challenging trend that humankind currently faces, and it is unlikely that we will ever lose the ability to answer it.

articles.title: The Missing Piece Of The $2 Trillion AI Market Is Human Psychology
articles.author: Mark Minevich
articles.summary: Global spending on artificial intelligence is projected to reach nearly $1.5 trillion in 2025. It's on pace to surpass $2 trillion in 2026. Human behavioral science may be the key to unlocking the true power of artificial intelligence. Organizations are coding behavioral science directly into their AI systems. The goal of this technology is to predict how humans will respond to data it processes.

articles.author: Game Rant
articles.summary: Aspyr has removed AI-generated content from Tomb Raider IV-VI remastered after being sued over its inclusion. AI has been cropping up a lot in recent years in the gaming industry. It's not the first time it's been used in this way.

articles.title: Chatbot site depicting child sexual abuse images raises fears over misuse of AI
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: A chatbot site offering explicit scenarios with preteen characters illustrated by illegal abuse images has raised fresh fears about the misuse of artificial intelligence. A report by a child safety watchdog has triggered calls for the UK government to impose safety guidelines on AI companies. There is a surge in child and teacher alone after class.

articles.title: First AI-powered virus prompts experts' call to boost cybersecurity
articles.author: Khaleejtimes
articles.summary: The world's first AI-powered virus, called PromptLock, has just emerged. It's built on open-source AI and can adapt on the fly to attack Windows, macOS and Linux machines. It hunts down your computer. Phishing remains one of the primary entry points for attackers in the region.

articles.title: Behind Grok's 'sexy' settings, workers review explicit and disturbing content
articles.author: system
articles.summary: xAI's chatbot, Grok, has several provocative functions. Some xAI workers have encountered NSFW content, including AI-generated child sexual abuse material. Experts say that if you don't draw a hard line at anything unpleasant, you will have a more complex problem with more gray areas.

articles.title: Elon Musk claims if we let robots take over we'll all have "best medical care, food, housing and a universal high income". And everybody gets an electric rainbow-sparkle farting pony too
articles.summary: IBM's ChatGPT and others are pushing AI that is not Cognition. It's a glorified statistician, NOT a sentient, not a sapient box that can come to its own genuine conclusions. The only thing capable of coping with an ever-shifting maze of potential problems that require real-time synthesis of actual solutions is an actual human.
